questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. She first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. She has often taken painful blows to the side of the knees while playing basketball but does not recall this having happened in the last game. Four weeks ago, she was diagnosed with a chlamydial urinary tract infection and treated with azithromycin. She is sexually active with one male partner; they use condoms inconsistently. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left anterior knee that is exacerbated with anterior pressure to the patella when the knee is fully extended; there is no erythema or swelling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome is one of the most common causes of anterior knee pain, especially in young, female athletes. This syndrome is characterized by retropatellar or peripatellar pain that worsens with activity (e.g., ascending and descending stairs) or after a period of prolonged sitting. The etiology is not definitively known but is thought to be caused by multiple factors, including overuse and malalignment of the knee joint. Treatment includes exercises to strengthen the quadriceps muscle.

The patellar grind test is not particularly helpful in diagnosing patellofemoral pain syndrome and may cause unnecessary pain for the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease can cause anterior knee pain that worsens with activity. However, this condition typically develops in a younger population (9–14 years of age) and is more common among boys (especially boys who recently experienced a growth spurt). In addition, Osgood-Schlatter disease usually causes proximal tibial swelling. Moreover, the pain caused by this condition is typically reproducible with extension against resistance, not with anterior patellar pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause knee pain and occur following an episode of genitourinary infection if there is hematogenous spread of the infection. However, the knee pain caused by septic arthritis is typically severe and accompanied by swelling, erythema, and fever. In addition, only a few of the pathogens that cause genitourinary infections are known to spread hematogenously to the joints (e.g., N. gonorrhea, E. coli, P. aeruginosa). This patient was treated for chlamydial infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome is a common cause of knee pain among athletes, especially those who run frequently. However, the pain caused by this syndrome is typically located on the lateral aspect of the knee near the lateral femoral condyle (the insertion site of the iliotibial band). In addition, the pain does not worsen with prolonged sitting but tends to be worse at the beginning of and during exercise. The diagnosis is confirmed if the pain experienced during exercise can be reproduced by exerting constant pressure on the lateral femoral condyle while passively flexing the knee.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury is common among basketball players and can cause knee pain. This injury is typically associated with an initial popping sound that is followed by knee instability. Although this patient recalls a history of minor trauma to the knee in the past, she neither felt a popping sensation nor any knee instability then or in this present episode.

F) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis can develop 1–4 weeks after a chlamydial infection and cause joint pain. However, this condition typically manifests with acute polyarthritis that is asymmetric and migratory in nature. In addition, this patient's knee pain worsens with sitting and is exacerbated by anterior patellar pressure; these findings are not typical features of reactive arthritis.

G) INCORRECT:

Patellar tendinitis is common among young athletes, especially those involved in sports that require frequent jumping (e.g., volleyball, basketball) and typically manifests with pain located on the anterior aspect of the knee which worsens with prolonged sitting and ascending and descending stairs. However, the pain is elicited when applying pressure to the inferior aspect of the knee cap or the tibial tuberosity (where the patellar tendon attaches to the tibia). Moreover, pressure on the knee cap during quadriceps activation does not typically recreate the pain.
questions.hint: The pain associated with this patient's condition is often poorly localized but patients typically describe the pain as worse under or around the patella. Some patients report an audible popping sound after prolonged sitting or when ascending or descending stairs.

Extremities: no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; dorsalis pedis, radial, and femoral pulses intact 
Musculoskeletal: tenderness to palpation over the medial and lateral patellar facets of the right knee; no associated effusion, erythema, joint line tenderness, or joint laxity; full, symmetric strength of quadriceps, hip abductors, and hip external rotators;
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Pain control and reevaluation in 3 days

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

PFPS is one of the most common diagnoses in sports medicine. This condition is thought to be caused by multiple factors, including overuse and malalignment of the knee joint. The diagnosis is established clinically when a patient presents with characteristic clinical features of PFPS without signs of other tibiofemoral pathology (e.g., locking, clicking, effusions, erythema, or warmth). Treatment of PFPS in the acute phase (the first 1–4 days, while there are clinical signs of active inflammation) consists of the POLICE principle, NSAIDs, and relative rest. During the recovery phase, physical therapy, hip and knee exercises (e.g., quadriceps strengthening), and temporary activity modification (switching to low-impact activities such as biking) are indicated. For a patient with typical manifestations of PFPS and no findings that suggest an alternative diagnosis (e.g., recent trauma, joint instability, joint effusion), imaging studies are not indicated as part of the initial management. In patients with persistent symptoms after a period of appropriate management (1–2 months), imaging studies should be obtained to exclude other pathologies.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy (e.g., quadriceps strengthening, stretching exercises) is recommended for the long-term treatment (i.e., the recovery phase) of patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). This patient, who has a 2-day history of knee pain, is currently in the acute phase of PFPS and should be treated with a different approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy of the knee is useful for diagnosing and treating intraarticular causes of knee pain, such as meniscal injury and cruciate ligament tears. However, these conditions usually develop secondary to acute trauma and manifest with joint instability on examination. This patient has PFPS, an extraarticular condition for which arthroscopy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies (e.g., MRI) can be used to exclude other, more serious pathologies. However, for this patient with typical manifestations and history of PFPS and no findings that suggest an alternative diagnosis (e.g., recent trauma, joint instability, joint effusion), imaging studies are not indicated as part of the initial management. In patients with persistent symptoms after a period of appropriate management (1–2 months), imaging studies should be obtained to exclude other pathologies.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is used to evaluate patients for intraarticular conditions, such as septic arthritis and gout. However, this patient's knee pain is most consistent with a diagnosis of PFPS, which is an extraarticular condition. She does not have manifestations of intraarticular pathology (e.g., erythema, joint effusion, local warmth). Synovial fluid analysis is, therefore, not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular steroid injection is not known to improve the symptoms of patellofemoral pain syndrome and is, therefore, not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. This treatment is more appropriate for patients with inflammatory arthritis (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis) or osteoarthritis.

G) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies (e.g., x-ray) can be used to exclude other more serious pathologies. However, for this patient with typical manifestations of PFPS and no findings that suggest an alternative diagnosis (e.g., recent trauma, joint instability, joint effusion), imaging studies are not indicated as part of the initial management. In patients with persistent symptoms after a period of appropriate management (1–2 months), imaging studies should be obtained to exclude other pathologies.
questions.hint: This patient's acute-onset peripatellar pain that worsens while squatting or after a period of prolonged sitting is highly characteristic of patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS), which is a common disorder among young, female athletes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right knee pain. The pain started suddenly when he collided with the catcher while sliding into home plate during a baseball game. It is sharp and constant and the patient has not been able to bear any weight on his right leg since then. He has no history of serious illness and his only medication is a creatine supplement that he takes to build up muscle. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a swollen right knee that is tender to palpation along the anterior aspects. He is unable to extend his knee against gravity. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-rays of his right knee show an effusion and the patella located proximal to the femoral condyles; there is no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute patellar tendon tears are most commonly caused by trauma to the infrapatellar region (e.g., sliding into home plate, chronic tendon degeneration) due to sudden contraction of the quadriceps. Physical examination typically reveals anterior knee pain, effusion, and an inability to extend the knee and keep the leg straight when flexing the hip. X-rays of the knee will show a high-riding patella because of unopposed quadriceps tendon force. Partial patellar tendon tear can usually be managed conservatively with immobilization and physical therapy, while complete patellar tendon tears are managed surgically with end-to-end suturing of the patellar tendon.

In contrast, a low-riding patella indicates a tear of the quadriceps tendon. (See “Distinguishing features of knee tendon injuries” table.)
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view)

The patella is abnormally high-riding (patella alta; normal position illustrated by outline). Although no fracture fragment is visible, a small defect at the patellar apex (green overlay) raises question of a prior avulsion fracture.

Patellar tendon rupture can result from trauma or systemic illness. A traumatic rupture usually occurs at either the patellar or tibial insertion site and may be accompanied by an avulsion fracture. A systemic illness usually results in a midtendon tear.

F: femur; T: tibia

B) INCORRECT:

Traumatic patellar subluxations typically manifest with anterior knee pain, swelling, and a restricted range of motion with the knee usually held in fixed flexion. However, x-rays of the knee almost always show a lateral displacement of the patella, rather than a high-riding patella.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view)

The patella (green overlay) is displaced laterally. It is normally located anterior to a groove between the femoral condyles (the patellofemoral groove; indicated by red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Meniscus tears most commonly manifest with knee pain and swelling, and restricted knee extension. However, knee pain is usually located at the medial or lateral joint line rather than the anterior part of the knee. Additionally, physical examination would most likely reveal clicking sounds or a locking sensation with knee extension; weight-bearing is usually not limited. Moreover, x-rays of the knee are typically unremarkable in meniscus tears.
Image Description:

MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears are most commonly caused by a twisting mechanism or direct blow to the knee and typically manifest with sudden-onset knee pain and swelling. However, patients with ACL tears typically report a popping sound upon injury and a positive Lachman test on physical examination, rather than an inability to extend the knee. X-rays of the knee are often normal but may show a deep lateral sulcus sign or tibial eminence avulsion fracture.
Image Description:

MRI of the knee (T1-weighted, coronal view)

Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament.

E) INCORRECT:

Quadriceps tendon tears are usually acute, caused by a sudden and strong contraction of the quadriceps muscles, and manifest with knee pain, effusion, and inability to extend the knee. However, the quadriceps tendon attaches to the superior aspect of the patella, so x-rays of the knee typically show a low-riding patella and a lack of quadriceps shadow rather than a high-riding patella.
Image Description:

Left: MRI knee (PD weighted (Fat Sat); sagittal plane)
Right: X-ray knee (lateral view)

MRI shows a quadriceps tendon tear (red overlay) accompanied by extensive hyperintense fluid (indicated by green arrowheads), including a joint effusion. The radiograph shows some soft tissue thickening in the suprapatellar region (green overlay) and a small calcification (yellow arrowhead).
questions.hint: This patient's knee x-ray findings are consistent with a high-riding patella.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe left ankle pain after she fell over a rock while hiking 2 hours ago. She took acetaminophen for the pain with only minimal relief. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple abrasions on both legs. The left ankle is edematous and has a restricted range of motion due to pain; she is unable to bear weight on the left foot. There is tenderness over the tip of the left medial malleolus. The pedal pulse is palpable. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. The left foot is elevated, additional analgesia is given, and ice is applied to the injured site. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain an MRI of the ankle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ankle support (e.g., semi-rigid ankle support, elastic wrap with a pneumatic walking boot) is indicated for patients with moderate grade II sprains, defined as an incomplete ligament injury with restricted range of motion, painful ambulation, and mild to moderate joint instability. However, as this patient also fulfills the criteria for suspected fracture according to the Ottawa ankle rules, a different step in management should be performed first.

B) CORRECT:

Pain over the tip of the malleolus and the inability to bear weight following an acute ankle injury should raise suspicion for a fracture, and a standard 3-view (anteroposterior, lateral, and mortise) x-ray series should be obtained. To determine whether an x-ray is indicated in ankle injuries, providers in the emergency room or doctor's office use the Ottawa ankle rules, which are highly sensitive for excluding fractures. The Ottawa ankle rules state that a plain radiograph of the ankle is indicated if there is tenderness at the posterior border or tip of either the medial or lateral malleolus, or if the patient is unable to bear weight, which is defined as the inability to take four steps or transfer weight to each foot twice. Regardless of whether a fracture is detected, RICE (rest, ice, compression, and elevation) is integral to the initial management of ankle injuries.
Image Description:

The Ottawa ankle and foot rules apply to patients presenting to the emergency department (ED) with traumatic ankle and/or foot injuries.

Ankle x-rays are indicated in the presence of pain in the malleolar zone AND one or both of the following:
- Tenderness along the posterior distal 6 cm of the lateral OR medial malleolus
- Inability to weight-bear both immediately post-injury AND for at least 4 steps in the ED

Foot x-rays are indicated in the presence of pain in the midfoot zone AND one or both of the following:
- Tenderness at the base of the 5th metatarsal OR the navicular bone
- Inability to weight-bear both immediately post-injury AND for at least 4 steps in the ED

C) INCORRECT:

A short-leg cast is indicated in stable ankle fractures for 4–6 weeks and for severe, grade III ankle sprains, both of which typically manifest with malleolar pain, swelling, and tenderness. However, unstable ankle fractures (i.e., posterior malleolus, bimalleolar, trimalleolar fractures) require surgical stabilization.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the ankle is indicated after acute injury if pain persists for over six weeks after initial, conventional treatment. While MRI is favored for detecting soft tissue injury (e.g., syndesmosis injury), it has not been shown to be better than plain radiography at detecting bony fractures in patients with acute injuries. Furthermore, if a fracture is suspected and a plain radiograph is inconclusive, a CT scan of the ankle is the preferred imaging modality.

E) INCORRECT:

Elastic bandages are indicated in ankle injuries as part of the RICE (rest, ice, compression, and elevation) principles and should be applied early after injury to minimize swelling. They can also be used in combination with another form of ankle support (e.g., pneumatic walking boot) to stabilize moderate ankle sprains with ligamentous injury. However, ankle sprains would not meet the criteria laid out in the Ottawa ankle rules.
questions.hint: The Ottawa ankle rules are used to guide management after an ankle injury.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left ankle pain and swelling for the last 4 days after she missed a step and fell down the stairs. She has been able to move around slowly but is worried because the pain has not subsided despite taking acetaminophen. She is otherwise healthy. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moderate swelling of the left ankle and tenderness along the anterior edge of the lateral malleolus. Range of motion at the left ankle joint is limited due to pain. Left dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+. She walks without a limp. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Protected weight bearing, cooling, and compression
Leg cast to immobilize the ankle

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ankle sprains are most commonly caused by injury of the anterior talofibular ligament due to excessive inversion of the foot. Conservative treatment for acute ankle sprains consists of protection, optimal loading, ice, compression, and elevation (POLICE principle), along with NSAIDs for analgesia. Immediately after the injury, patients should undergo a brief period of relative rest followed by mobilization exercises within a pain-free range and protected weight bearing. Conservative treatment is indicated in patients with normal x-rays and in those who do not require imaging according to the Ottawa ankle rules. Accordingly, because this patient is able to bear weight on the ankle and does not have point tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral or medial malleolus, x-rays are not required.

If ankle instability or severe pain is present, a cast boot or short leg cast can be used for a few days. Surgery may be indicated if there is ligament rupture, especially in patients who are likely to experience continuous stress on the ankle joint, such as professional athletes.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical reconstruction of ankle ligaments may be considered in patients with chronic ankle instability, as evidenced by recurrent ankle sprains, or in patients with a complete tear of the ligament who are likely to experience continuous stress at the ankle joint (e.g., professional athletes). This patient does not experience recurrent ankle sprains and has no signs of a ruptured ligament (e.g., ecchymosis, ankle instability, inability to bear weight).

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the ankle is used to assess ankle sprains that do not respond to conservative therapy (i.e., pain persists after 6–8 weeks). This patient is only 4 days post-injury and in the acute setting, an MRI has no advantage over x-rays.

D) INCORRECT:

A leg cast is used to immobilize the ankle in patients who have an ankle fracture or an ankle sprain with severe pain and ankle instability (grade III sprain). Usually, these patients cannot bear weight on the affected ankle. This patient, however, has been able to bear weight for the past 4 days. Moreover, an ankle fracture or grade III sprain manifests with severe pain, swelling, ecchymosis, ankle instability, and tenderness along the malleolus, whereas this patient only has moderate swelling, no ecchymosis, and a stable ankle joint.

E) INCORRECT:

The Ottawa ankle rules are used to determine whether a patient with foot pain requires an x-ray. Imaging is indicated for patients who are unable to bear weight on the affected foot or have tenderness at the posterior edge of the medial or lateral malleolus. As this patient is able to bear weight and pain is localized to the anterior edge of the malleolus, x-rays are not indicated.
questions.hint: The combination of ankle pain, swelling, limited range of motion, tenderness along the anterior lateral malleolus, and preserved ability to bear weight after a traumatic event suggests a lateral ankle sprain.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left ankle pain and swelling for the last 4 days after missing a step and rolling her left ankle with the sole of her foot facing inward. She has been able to move around slowly but is worried because the pain has not subsided despite taking acetaminophen. Medical history is unremarkable. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical examination reveals:

Moderate swelling of the left ankle
Tenderness along the anterior edge of the lateral malleolus
Limited range of motion at the left ankle joint due to pain
Palpable left dorsalis pedis pulse
Left fibular head restricted in anterior glide

Which of the following ligaments are most likely damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The posterior talofibular ligament may be involved in a supination ankle sprain, but the deltoid ligament is medial and injured in pronation rather than supination sprains.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior tibiofibular ligament is injured in high ankle sprains, which are less common than low supination sprains. The tibiocalcaneal ligament is part of the deltoid ligament, which is medial and injured in pronation rather than supination sprains.

C) INCORRECT:

The posterior talocalcaneal and deltoid ligaments are medial and involved in pronation rather than supination ankle sprains.

D) CORRECT:

Supination ankle sprains typically involve injury to the lateral stabilizers of the ankle, which are anterior talofibular (ATFL), posterior talofibular (PTFL), and calcaneofibular (CFL) ligaments; the ATFL is most commonly affected. Ankle sprains are classified by the extent of ligamentous involvement: type I involves only ATFL, type II involves ATFL and CFL, and type III involves all three ligaments.
Image Description:

Lateral view

E) INCORRECT:

The posterior talofibular (PTFL) and calcaneofibular (CFL) ligaments are lateral stabilizers of the ankle. PTFL and CFL ligaments may be injured in low supination ankle sprains, but they are always injured in combination with another lateral stabilizer.

F) INCORRECT:

The anterior tibiofibular ligament is injured in high ankle sprains, which are less common than low supination sprains. The deltoid ligament is a medial ligament of the ankle and is injured in pronation rather than supination sprains.
questions.hint: Swelling and tenderness along the lateral malleolus indicates an inversion, or supination, ankle sprain. Ankle supination pulls the distal fibula anteriorly, often resulting in a posterior fibular head dysfunction. The ligaments most likely damaged are those that prevent excessive supination of the ankle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the office with a 1-week history of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. She first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. She has often taken painful blows to the side of the knees while playing basketball but does not recall this having happened in the last game. Physical examination reveals dull tenderness with pressure to the left anterior knee without erythema or swelling. The patella deviates sideways when the patient brings her knee into full extension. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patellar tendinitis is common among young athletes, especially those involved in sports that require frequent jumping (e.g., volleyball, basketball) and typically manifests with pain located on the anterior aspect of the knee which worsens with prolonged sitting and ascending and descending stairs. The pain is elicited when applying pressure to the inferior aspect of the knee cap or the tibial tuberosity (where the patellar tendon attaches to the tibia). Additionally, patellofemoral maltracking isn't a typical manifestation of patellar tendinitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease can cause anterior knee pain that worsens with activity and is associated with patellar complications including patellofemoral maltracking. This condition typically develops in a younger population (9–14 years of age) and is more common among boys (especially boys who recently experienced a growth spurt). In addition, Osgood-Schlatter disease usually causes proximal tibial swelling. Moreover, the pain caused by this condition is typically reproducible with extension against resistance, not with anterior patellar pressure.

C) CORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome is one of the most common causes of anterior knee pain, especially in young, female athletes. This syndrome is characterized by retropatellar or peripatellar pain that worsens with activity (e.g., ascending and descending stairs) or after a period of prolonged sitting. There is no definitive cause of patellofemoral pain syndrome, but it has been associated with an imbalance in the quadriceps, in particular, a vastus medialis that is weaker than the vastus lateralis. This imbalance can lead to abnormal tracking of the patella (e.g., lateral deviation) through the femoral groove. Osteopathic treatment includes exercises to strengthen the vastus medialis muscle.

The patellar grind test is not particularly helpful in diagnosing patellofemoral pain syndrome and may cause unnecessary pain for the patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament injury is common among basketball players and can cause knee pain. This injury is typically associated with an initial popping sound that is followed by knee instability. Although this patient recalls a history of minor trauma to the knee in the past, she neither felt a popping sensation nor any knee instability then or in this present episode. Additionally, anterior cruciate ligament injury does not manifest with patellofemoral maltracking.

E) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome is a common cause of knee pain among athletes, especially those who run frequently, and may be associated with patellofemoral maltracking. The pain caused by this syndrome is typically located on the lateral aspect of the knee near the lateral femoral condyle (the insertion site of the iliotibial band). In addition, the pain does not worsen with prolonged sitting but tends to be worse at the beginning of and during exercise. The diagnosis is confirmed if the pain experienced during exercise can be reproduced by exerting constant pressure on the lateral femoral condyle while passively flexing the knee.
questions.hint: The pain associated with this patient's condition is often poorly localized, but patients typically describe the pain as worse under or around the patella. Some patients report an audible popping sound after prolonged sitting or when ascending or descending stairs.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with bilateral anterior knee pain. She has no medical history or recent trauma and takes no medications. She has been going to the gym regularly for the past 3 months. The knee pain, which started about a month ago, is mild but is beginning to affect her workouts. The pain is worst when she descends stairs, squats, or sits with her knees bent. Acetaminophen and ibuprofen have provided no relief.
On examination, she has mild anterior tenderness in both knees, normal range of motion without exacerbation of pain, and no effusions. McMurray, anterior drawer, and posterior drawer tests are negative. There is mild tenderness with compression of the patella.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis is usually caused by repeated trauma such as prolonged kneeling. It typically manifests unilaterally as swelling and tenderness of the bursa, which overlies the patella.

B) CORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) — the most common cause of nontraumatic knee pain in young, active adults — often occurs in women, particularly athletes such as runners, bicyclists, and basketball players. Although the specific etiology of the condition is still unknown, it is thought to be related to overuse, malalignment, or trauma.

Many physical examination maneuvers and measurements of radiographs have been proposed for assisting with the diagnosis of PFPS, but none has high sensitivity or specificity. The diagnosis, therefore, is mainly based on a history of anterior knee pain that worsens with squatting, running, sitting for prolonged periods, or using stairs. The mainstay of treatment for PFPS is physical therapy, aimed at quadriceps strengthening, along with rest, ice, and analgesics.

Key learning point: A common underlying cause of anterior knee pain in a young, active adult is patellofemoral pain syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A popliteal cyst, or Baker cyst, manifests as swelling of the popliteal fossa. It results from enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa secondary to trauma, inflammatory disease, or osteoarthritis. In older patients with osteoarthritis or other knee pathology, a popliteal cyst often communicates with the knee joint space.

D) INCORRECT:

Patellar tendinitis typically occurs due to repeated strain from activities involving jumping (e.g., gymnastics or basketball). It is usually characterized by tenderness to palpation at the patellar-tendon insertion at the proximal tibia and is often reproduced by resisted knee extension.

E) INCORRECT:

A meniscal tear will often manifest with pain, swelling, and symptoms such as locking, clicking, or give-way instability.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports a 4-week history of pain in her left knee. The pain begins insidiously at the anterior surface of her knee during her regular jogging routine and persists for about an hour afterward. She also notices this pain transiently when she switches from a sitting to a standing position, when she sits for long periods of time, and when she descends stairs. Stretching out her knee passively relieves the pain. She reports no morning stiffness.
Physical examination reveals the absence of swelling, erythema, or limited range of motion. Palpation around the knee does not produce pain, but pushing the patella medially or laterally produces mild pain. The patient has no pain at rest but exhibits some anterior knee pain with resisted extension of the left knee. The remainder of the musculoskeletal examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anserine bursitis features focal tenderness at the attachment site of the hamstring tendons on the medial aspect of the tibia, distal to the joint space.

B) INCORRECT:

A stress fracture does not usually produce subjective abnormalities on physical examination other than focal tenderness, and pain is usually perceived immediately with any bearing of weight.

C) INCORRECT:

Findings that suggest inflammatory arthritis include warmth felt over the knee or an effusion. Osteoarthritis is unlikely in a young woman in the absence of severe obesity, prior trauma, or congenital abnormality.

D) CORRECT:

In a young, active patient, anterior knee pain that is exacerbated by activity or by prolonged sitting is most consistent with a diagnosis of patellofemoral pain syndrome. Other diagnoses such as inflammatory arthritis, stress fracture, tendinitis, and bursitis should also be considered and can usually be ruled out by physical examination. In contrast, patients with patellofemoral syndrome often have pain that is reproduced on examination with manipulation of the patella, resisted use of the quadriceps muscles, and/or squatting, but no physical examination technique has been identified that is sufficiently sensitive and specific to be considered diagnostic. Thus, the diagnosis is mainly based on a history of anterior knee pain that worsens with squatting, running, sitting for prolonged periods, or using stairs.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a young woman who has anterior knee pain with activity and whose physical examination elicits pain with some maneuvers but yields no specific findings is patellofemoral pain syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis causes localized tenderness and swelling on the anterior aspect of the patella, a finding that can be easily seen on examination.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents with an ankle injury that occurred as he came down from a rebound during a basketball game yesterday. He landed on another player and inverted his foot. He was able to walk after the injury.
The patient can walk down the hallway, but he has an antalgic gait. There is swelling and ecchymosis about the lateral ankle, as well as tenderness anterior and inferior to the lateral malleolus. No bony tenderness to the ankle or foot is evident, nor is there any tenderness to the fibular head. A squeeze and rotation test is negative. An anterior drawer and a talar tilt test are positive.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend rest, ice, compression, and elevation and apply an air-stirrup brace
Obtain a radiograph of the ankle
Temporarily immobilize in a walking cast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiinflammatory medications may help to reduce pain and swelling but should be used as an adjunct to a compression wrap with an air-stirrup or lace-up brace.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient should be managed initially with rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) to help reduce pain and swelling. Placing the patient in an air-stirrup brace in combination with a compression wrap facilitates quicker return to preinjury function than using either approach alone. Alternatively, the patient may be placed in a lace-up support brace, which provides a similar reduction in swelling and facilitates a similarly rapid return to activity.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with a lateral ankle sprain. A positive anterior drawer test suggests injury to the anterior talofibular ligament. A positive talar tilt test suggests injury to the calcaneofibular ligament.

This patient should be managed initially with rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) to help reduce pain and swelling. Placing the patient in an air-stirrup brace in combination with a compression wrap facilitates quicker return to preinjury function than using either approach alone. It also provides speedier return than placement in a walking cast. Alternatively, the patient may be placed in a lace-up support brace, which provides a similar reduction in swelling and facilitates a similarly rapid return to activity.

Ultimately, this patient should be reexamined for continued ligamentous laxity before returning to athletics. He is likely to need rehabilitation with strengthening and proprioception training to help prevent recurrent injury.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial management for a lateral ankle sprain is RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation) and an air-stirrup or lace-up brace.

D) INCORRECT:

The Ottawa foot and ankle rules can be used in adult and pediatric populations to help determine whether radiographs are needed after an injury. Given that this patient could walk immediately after the injury and that he exhibits no tenderness to the posterior edge or tip of the medial malleolus or lateral malleolus, no tenderness to the navicular bone, and no tenderness to the base of the fifth metatarsal, he does not need ankle imaging. The absence of a positive compression and rotation test indicate that syndesmotic injury has not occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients should be immobilized in a walking cast only if they are unable to walk because of pain. Range-of-motion exercises and weight-bearing should start as soon as they can be tolerated, to prevent stiffness and to quicken the return to activity.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman has a 2-week history of bilateral lower-extremity pain that developed after she began a new running program. She has never previously had this type of pain, which she describes as a deep ache over the medial aspect of both shins that worsens with running. The pain sometimes lingers after activity while she is at rest.
Her physical examination is notable for bilateral pes planus, tenderness to palpation nonfocally over the distal two-thirds of both posteromedial tibial surfaces, normal ankle and knee examinations, and an intact lower-extremity neurovascular status.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medial tibial stress syndrome (shin splints) is a common cause of distal lower-extremity pain in runners. Affected patients describe pain that is associated with activity, sometimes improves with continued training, and often persists at rest after activity. Among the numerous proposed risk factors are female sex, pes planus, excessive pronation, and recent increases in training intensity.

The pathophysiology of medial tibial stress syndrome is thought to involve a combination of traction on the periosteum by the calf muscles and repetitive bending loads across the tibia. Classic physical examination findings include tenderness to palpation of the distal two-thirds of the posteromedial tibial surfaces. This patient has some of the aforementioned risk factors as well as a history and physical examination consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome.

Conservative treatment is usually successful for patients with medial tibial stress syndrome and includes rest, ice, compression, elevation, pre- and postexercise stretching, short-term activity modification, and correction of any risk factors, such as pes planus or excessive pronation.

Key learning point: In a patient who recently initiated a new running program, the presence of bilateral lower-extremity pain that is most prominent over the distal two-thirds of the posteromedial tibial surfaces is most consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome (shin splints).

B) INCORRECT:

Tibial stress fractures are usually unilateral and have a more chronic progression associated with high-intensity and high-volume training. The pain is often over the proximal third of the tibia and tends to become more focal as the condition progresses.

C) INCORRECT:

Tibialis posterior tendinopathy is a chronic injury associated with high-impact activities. The pain is usually more distal over the medial aspects of the foot and ankle, and it can involve associated edema inferomedial to the medial malleolus. It typically manifests only during activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrocalcaneal bursitis is an acute overuse injury involving inflammation of the bursa posterior to the calcaneus and anterior to the Achilles tendon. Pain is experienced during activity and is often worse after activity during rest periods. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness and swelling to palpation in this area. Tight footwear that exerts pressure on this location often causes and exacerbates this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic exertional compartment syndrome typically involves pain and/or numbness and tingling of the calf muscles or feet. It occurs only during activity and typically stops within minutes after the offending activity is discontinued.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman who plays college basketball reports a 4-week history of right anterior knee pain. The pain, located behind the patella, is exacerbated by squatting, sitting for prolonged periods, ascending or descending stairs, and playing basketball for at least 20 minutes. The patient does not recall a specific mechanism of injury and reports no swelling of the knee joint.
There is slight lateral tracking of the patella, with a reproducible pain as the patient’s patella is pushed into the trochlear groove with the knee in full extension. There is audible grinding when pressure is applied to the patella while the knee is actively flexed and extended. The rest of the examination for any ligamentous or meniscus pathology is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer an intra-articular glucocorticoid knee injection
Recommend a program of quadriceps strengthening exercises

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot orthoses can help to correct excessive foot pronation that contributes to the underlying condition, but it is a second-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Injection of a glucocorticoid into the intra-articular knee joint is rarely used to treat PFPS; it can be considered if conservative management fails.

C) INCORRECT:

PFPS is most effectively managed by correcting patellar misalignment. This can be achieved through a quadriceps strengthening program. Patellar taping and bracing may be added, but strengthening of the quadriceps remains the mainstay of treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

PFPS is most effectively managed by correcting patellar misalignment. This can be achieved through a quadriceps strengthening program. Patellar taping and bracing may be added, but strengthening of the quadriceps remains the mainstay of treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) is a common orthopedic complaint (more so in females than males) whose exact etiology is unknown. It is thought to have multiple causes, including joint impairment, altered lower-extremity biomechanics, and overuse. Repetitive shearing forces, such as jumping in volleyball or basketball, are thought to play a role. The characteristic pain is located behind the kneecap and worsens with squatting, sitting for prolonged periods, and ascending or descending stairs. The patient often exhibits diffuse pain around the patella and may have a positive patellar grind test (reproducible pain with the knee in full extension and the patella pushed posterior into the trochlear groove).

Other causes of anterior knee pain include prepatellar bursitis and patellar tendinitis. Prepatellar bursitis — which typically manifests with swelling of the knee, difficulty with ambulation, and inability to kneel on the affected side — is frequently seen in occupations that require constant kneeling. Patellar tendinitis is characterized by pain that is most commonly felt along the inferior pole of the patella and the patellar tendon.

PFPS is most effectively managed by correcting patellar misalignment. This can be achieved through a quadriceps strengthening program, either in the form of a home exercise program or through formal physical therapy. Patellar taping and bracing may be added, but strengthening of the quadriceps remains the mainstay of treatment.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for a patient with patellofemoral pain syndrome is quadriceps strengthening.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl has a 2-day history of right ankle pain after an eversion injury that occurred when she was tackled during a soccer game. She has pain over the medial aspect of her ankle, with associated swelling and bruising that developed shortly after the injury. She has never had an injury like this before.
Tenderness, edema, and ecchymoses are evident over the right ankle’s lateral malleolus. She is especially tender to palpation over the distal fibula and anterior talofibular ligament. The edema and pain limit her range of motion and render an anterior drawer test inconclusive.
A radiograph of the right ankle is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for MRI imaging in the acute phase of an ankle sprain.

B) INCORRECT:

A long-leg walking cast is not required to achieve the necessary immobilization in this setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Early range-of-motion exercises are contraindicated given the potential for physeal injury.

D) CORRECT:

This girl is skeletally immature, and her radiograph reveals open physes. Her injury is consistent with a typical eversion ankle sprain. However, on examination, she has tenderness to palpation of the distal fibula in the area of her physis. Although her radiograph is normal, a Salter-Harris type I injury cannot be ruled out and must be assumed when considering a management approach, to avoid premature physeal closure. Without appropriate management, premature physeal closure in a Salter-Harris type I injury has an incidence of 2% to 40%. Correct management consists of immobilization in a short-leg walking cast or a pneumatic walking boot for up to 6 weeks.

Rest, ice, compression, and elevation may also help relieve symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a school-age child with open physes who sustains an ankle eversion sprain is use of a pneumatic walking boot or short-leg walking cast for up to 6 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication may provide analgesia and reduce inflammation, and over-the-counter preparations are adequate for these purposes. However, immobilization is the most important component of treatment.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old female marathon runner presents with pain that she initially described as aching in the right groin after activity. Now she reports pain in the groin, the pubic area, anterior hip, and lower abdomen. The pain is exacerbated by running and with pushing off to change direction.
There is tenderness to the pubic bone over the pubic symphysis, and symptoms are reproduced when applying pressure to the pubic ramus on the right side. In addition, the patient experiences pain when she is lying on her side with the right side down and she actively adducts the right leg while downward resistance is applied to the distal medial femur.
There is no pain with hip flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR) testing, nor with rolling of the extended leg into internal rotation when the patient is lying supine. Resisted sit-up and leg elevation do not reproduce symptoms.
Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Athletic pubalgia is a soft-tissue injury in the groin area. Although it is sometimes referred to as a sports hernia, a true hernia is not present. Athletic pubalgia is a clinical diagnosis characterized by unilateral pain in the groin and pain with resisted sit-up and leg elevation.

B) INCORRECT:

Femoral acetabular impingement (FAI) is caused by a cam- or pincer-bone spur that leads to joint damage and pain. Pain in the groin with a hip flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR) test suggests FAI.

C) INCORRECT:

Painful osteoarthritis of the hip is unlikely to have developed in a patient before her 30s.

D) CORRECT:

Osteitis pubis is most common in athletes who participate in sports with running, kicking, and rapid lateral movements. It is generally classified as an overuse injury that causes inflammation of the pubic symphysis from repetitive microtrauma, shearing forces, or both. The adductor and abdominal muscles attach near the pubic symphysis, exerting a pulling force on the symphysis when contracting (e.g., during running, kicking, or sit-ups). When the pain is chronic, a radiograph may show changes in the pubis symphysis, with combinations of sclerosis and lucency.

The most specific physical examination test for osteitis pubis is the direct-pressure spring test, in which the pubic bone is palpated over the pubic symphysis, which generally elicits tenderness. The fingers are then slid a few centimeters laterally to each side, applying pressure on the pubic rami. The test is positive when pain over the pubic symphysis is reproduced with ipsilateral pressure to the pubic rami. A thigh adduction test may be helpful; a positive test elicits exacerbation of pain because the adductor muscles are attached near the pubic symphysis.

Key learning point: The most specific test for osteitis pubis is a direct-pressure spring test.

E) INCORRECT:

Snapping hip syndrome is a benign condition that results from movement, or “snapping,” of the iliopsoas or rectus femoris tendon over a bony protrusion.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl has a 2-week history of bilateral lower-extremity pain that developed after she began her first high school track season. She has never previously had this type of pain, which she describes as a deep ache over the medial aspect of both lower legs between the knee and ankle that worsens with running. The pain sometimes lingers after activity while she is at rest.
Her physical examination is notable for bilateral pes planus, tenderness to palpation nonfocally over the distal two-thirds of both posteromedial tibial surfaces, normal ankle and knee examinations, and an intact lower-extremity neurovascular status.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease, or osteochondritis of the tibial tubercle, is commonly seen in preteen and teenage athletes who are not skeletally mature. Affected patients typically have anterior knee pain worsened by exercise. On physical examination, the classic finding is tenderness over the tibial tubercle(s).

B) INCORRECT:

Tibialis posterior tendinopathy is a chronic injury associated with high-impact activities. The pain is usually more distal over the medial aspects of the foot and ankle, and it can involve associated edema inferomedial to the medial malleolus. It typically manifests only during activity.

C) CORRECT:

Medial tibial stress syndrome (shin splints) is a common cause of distal lower-extremity pain in runners. Affected patients describe pain that is associated with activity, sometimes improves with continued training, and often persists at rest after activity. Among the numerous proposed risk factors are female sex, pes planus, excessive pronation, and recent increases in training intensity.

The pathophysiology of medial tibial stress syndrome is thought to involve a combination of traction on the periosteum by the calf muscles and repetitive bending loads across the tibia. Classic physical examination findings include tenderness to palpation of the distal two-thirds of the posteromedial tibial surfaces. This patient has some of the aforementioned risk factors as well as a history and physical examination consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome.

Conservative treatment is usually successful for patients with medial tibial stress syndrome and includes rest, ice, compression, elevation, pre- and postexercise stretching, short-term activity modification, and correction of any risk factors, such as pes planus or excessive pronation.

Key learning point: In a patient who recently initiated a new running program, the presence of bilateral lower-extremity pain that is most prominent over the distal two-thirds of the posteromedial tibial surfaces is most consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome (shin splints).

D) INCORRECT:

Tibial stress fractures are usually unilateral and have a more chronic progression associated with high-intensity and high-volume training. The pain is often over the proximal third of the tibia and tends to become more focal as the condition progresses.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic exertional compartment syndrome typically involves pain and/or numbness and tingling of the calf muscles or feet. It occurs only during activity and typically stops within minutes after the offending activity is discontinued.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a chief complaint of bilateral lower-leg pain. The pain has worsened since she first noticed it yesterday.
Two days ago, she went for a longer run with more hills than usual; she did not stretch before running. There was no injury, and she had no pain during or immediately after the run. She is not experiencing any numbness or tingling in her legs or feet. Ice, ibuprofen, and elevation have provided some relief.
No swelling or deformity of the lower extremities is evident. She has normal sensation, intact peripheral pulses, and brisk capillary refill. The ankles and knees are normal. There is no focal palpable tenderness of the tibia or fibula — and no increase in tenderness to palpation medial and lateral to the anterior tibia. There is no pain with passive stretching of the toes or foot. There is mild diffuse tenderness over the rest of the calves bilaterally. Strength is normal.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Compartment syndrome of the anterior compartment of the lower leg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures of the leg cause pain with activity and are typically associated with bone tenderness at the site of injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Medial tibial stress syndrome (shin splints) causes pain during exercise, improves with rest, and is associated with tenderness along the lower medial border of the tibia.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle strains cause pain at the time of injury or very soon thereafter, and the symptoms are more localized than they are in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome usually develops after a traumatic injury. An athlete may develop a chronic compartment syndrome related to exercise, often running. The patient usually has gradually increasing pain in a specific muscle area of the lower leg during physical exertion. The pain develops shortly after the onset of activity, and the patient may be able to describe how much exercise is required to elicit the symptoms. Pain with passive stretching of the foot or toes is one of the hallmarks of compartment syndrome. The pain resolves completely with rest but not immediately after discontinuation of exercise.

E) CORRECT:

Delayed-onset muscle soreness typically occurs 24 to 48 hours after exercise, often after initiation of a new exercise program, especially one involving eccentric exercises. The pathophysiology is not fully understood, but possible theories involve lactic acid, muscle spasm, connective-tissue damage, muscle damage, inflammation, and enzyme efflux. In addition to pain, delayed-onset muscle soreness can also cause weakness, tenderness, stiffness, and swelling. Pain severity peaks 1 to 3 days after the inciting activity and resolves within 7 days. Symptoms and examination findings distinguish delayed-onset muscle soreness from other causes of musculoskeletal pain.

Key learning point: Muscle pain that develops 24 to 48 hours after exercise, without a history of trauma or acute injury, and that is often associated with eccentric exercises is called delayed-onset muscle soreness.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, presents 2 days after feeling a pop along the back of his thigh while running. The pain, which prevented him from returning to activity, is exacerbated by ambulation. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications have provided some relief.
He has tenderness and visible ecchymosis along the posterior-medial aspect of his upper leg; there is no tenderness at the ischial tuberosity. Resisted knee flexion demonstrates minor weakness and reproduces the pain.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI is not indicated in this case because the presentation is typical for hamstring strain, which can be managed conservatively without imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Platelet-rich plasma therapy has unclear benefits for hamstring strains and should not be routinely recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Complete immobilization with a cast is unnecessary and may slow recovery if contractures form and range of motion decreases.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is appropriate when complete avulsion of the hamstring from the ischial tuberosity is suspected or apparent. Complete rupture manifests with severely limited range of motion, ecchymosis, palpable muscle defect, and pain along the ischial tuberosity.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has an acute, uncomplicated hamstring strain. The typical injury that provokes a hamstring strain is due to acute loading that occurs during hip flexion and knee extension, such as when running. Affected patients often describe experiencing a popping sensation when the injury occurs. In the acute setting, the pain often prevents patients from returning to activity.

Moderate-severity (grade II) hamstring strains, as seen in this patient, may manifest with posterior thigh ecchymosis as well as diminished strength and pain provoked by resisted knee flexion on physical examination. A mild (grade I) hamstring strain would manifest with slight pain, no reduction in strength, and no ecchymosis.

Appropriate initial management for a hamstring strain includes rest, ice, compression, and antiinflammatory medications. Therapy should begin with a strengthening program, and the return to activity should be gradual (4 to 6 weeks) because these injuries heal slowly.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for an acute, uncomplicated hamstring strain is rest, ice, and compression.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute right knee pain that developed during a recreational basketball game. She had stopped suddenly while running down the court and felt a sudden pain and pop in the anterior aspect of her knee. She was unable to bear weight and had to leave the game.
For the past 6 months, she has been experiencing mild right anterior knee pain. The pain has not limited her ability to play basketball because she has been managing it with a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, a patellar strap, and post-game icing.
On examination, her knee is swollen, and she has generalized tenderness of the anterior aspect of her knee. Radiographs reveal patella alta and an effusion but no fracture or dislocation (figure; dotted line indicates normal patella position).
Which one of the following findings is most likely during further examination of this patient's knee?

choices.text: Pain on a patellar apprehension test
Inability to actively extend the knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament tear (which would produce laxity on a Lachman test) and meniscus tear (which would cause pain on a McMurray test) can also occur with a deceleration injury. However, there is often a change in direction or a cutting maneuver during the deceleration. Neither of these injuries would produce evidence of patella alta on radiography.

B) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament tear (which would produce laxity on a Lachman test) and meniscus tear (which would cause pain on a McMurray test) can also occur with a deceleration injury. However, there is often a change in direction or a cutting maneuver during the deceleration. Neither of these injuries would produce evidence of patella alta on radiography.

C) INCORRECT:

A quadriceps rupture results in a palpable suprapatellar gap and evidence of patella baja on radiography.

D) INCORRECT:

Patellar apprehension corresponds with a patellar dislocation or subluxation. This might cause a popping sensation, but patella alta would not be seen on radiography.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history and radiographic findings are consistent with a patellar tendon rupture.

Patellar tendon rupture can occur when an individual suddenly decelerates with the foot planted and the knee flexed, which applies a strong force to the patellar tendon. It tends to occur in people younger than age 40, whereas quadriceps tendon ruptures generally occur in patients older than age 40. Underlying tendinosis often creates a predisposition to tendon rupture. Patellar tendon rupture should be suspected when a patient has an acute knee injury and an inability to actively extend the knee. Other findings include a high-riding patella (patella alta) on examination and radiography.

Key learning point: For patients with patellar tendon rupture, the knee movement that is most difficult is extension.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with an ankle injury that occurred as he came down from a rebound during a basketball game yesterday. He landed on another player and inverted his foot. He was able to walk after the injury.
The patient can walk down the hallway, but he has an antalgic gait. There is swelling and ecchymosis about the lateral ankle, as well as tenderness anterior and inferior to the lateral malleolus. No bony tenderness to the ankle or foot is evident, nor is there any tenderness to the fibular head. A squeeze and rotation test is negative. An anterior drawer and a talar tilt test are positive.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Temporarily immobilize in a walking cast
Obtain a radiograph of the ankle
Recommend rest, ice, compression, and elevation and apply an air-stirrup brace

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients should be immobilized in a walking cast only if they are unable to walk because of pain. Range-of-motion exercises and weight-bearing should start as soon as they can be tolerated, to prevent stiffness and to quicken the return to activity.

B) INCORRECT:

The Ottawa foot and ankle rules can be used in adult and pediatric populations to help determine whether radiographs are needed after an injury. Given that this patient could walk immediately after the injury and that he exhibits no tenderness to the posterior edge or tip of the medial malleolus or lateral malleolus, no tenderness to the navicular bone, and no tenderness to the base of the fifth metatarsal, he does not need ankle imaging. The absence of a positive compression and rotation test indicate that syndesmotic injury has not occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiinflammatory medications may help to reduce pain and swelling but should be used as an adjunct to a compression wrap with an air-stirrup or lace-up brace.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with a lateral ankle sprain. A positive anterior drawer test suggests injury to the anterior talofibular ligament. A positive talar tilt test suggests injury to the calcaneofibular ligament.

This patient should be managed initially with rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) to help reduce pain and swelling. It also provides speedier return than placement in a walking cast. Alternatively, the patient may be placed in a lace-up support brace, which provides a similar reduction in swelling and facilitates a similarly rapid return to activity.

Antiinflammatory medications may help to reduce pain and swelling but should be used as an adjunct to a compression wrap with an air-stirrup or lace-up brace.

Ultimately, this patient should be reexamined for continued ligamentous laxity before returning to athletics. He is likely to need rehabilitation with strengthening and proprioception training to help prevent recurrent injury.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial management for a lateral ankle sprain is RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation) and an air-stirrup or lace-up brace.

E) INCORRECT:

Placing the patient in an air-stirrup brace in combination with a compression wrap facilitates quicker return to preinjury function than using either approach alone.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female basketball player reports a 4-week history of right anterior knee pain. The pain, located behind the patella, is exacerbated by squatting, sitting for prolonged periods, ascending or descending stairs, and playing basketball for at least 20 minutes. The patient does not recall a specific mechanism of injury and reports no swelling of the knee joint.
There is slight lateral tracking of the patella, with a reproducible pain as the patient’s patella is pushed into the trochlear groove with the knee in full extension. There is audible grinding when pressure is applied to the patella while the knee is actively flexed and extended. B) INCORRECT:

C) CORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) is a common orthopedic complaint (more so in females than males) whose exact etiology is unknown. The characteristic pain is located behind the kneecap and worsens with squatting, sitting for prolonged periods, and ascending or descending stairs. This can be achieved through a quadriceps strengthening program, either in the form of a home exercise program or through formal physical therapy.
